metadata.title: Nanomaterials from biological and pharmaceutical wastes – a step towards environmental protection

sections.text:
2214-7853 © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. Selection and/or Peer-review under responsibility of International Conference on Nanotechnology: Ideas, Innovations & Initiatives-2017 (ICN:3i2017).
In this study, a novel technique of utilizing effectively the environment polluting wastes like expired medicines (Norflox-TZ, present case) and chicken processing discard is reported with a conviction that such wastes too could participate in nanoparticle synthesis. This effort may help in controlling the environmental pollution and subsequently the different diseases. A simple environment friendly protocol, employing the broths of chicken processing discard (principally intestine) and expired Norflox-TZ yielded Ag as well as ZnO nanoparticles. X-ray and transmission electron microscopy analyses are performed to ascertain the formation of Ag and ZnO nanoparticles. Possible involved mechanisms for the biosynthesis of Ag and ZnO nanoparticles using chicken processing discard and expired Norflox-TZ have also been discussed. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. Selection and/or Peer-review under responsibility of International Conference on Nanotechnology: Ideas, Innovations & Initiatives-2017 (ICN:3i2017).
Keywords: Nanomaterials; Waste minimization; Green approach; Biosynthesis; Bionanotechnology; Environmental pollution

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The growth and development of humanity is all around, but this pace has left many scars on the environment. We have left no natural resource intact by changing its basic chemistry, better perceived as pollution. Along with the regular menace of other pollutants (viz.: air, water, noise, soil, and radiation) we are experiencing a massive threat from Biological Wastes and Expired Pharmaceuticals. Both are hidden but are potentially annihilating. Every year
* Corresponding author. Tel.: +91-641-2501699; fax: +91-641-2501699. E-mail address: prasad_k@tmbuniv.ac.in
1466 A.K. Jha and K. Prasad / Materials Today: Proceedings 18 (2019) 1465–1471
medicines are being expired all through the world and they have two common fates: either they are being burnt or are flushed to the aquatic system; in both the cases, they are posing potential threat to the environment. As they not only add up to the air pollution, if burnt rather also produce next robust generation of microbes (Bacteria and Fungi) resistant against that pharmaceutical. Different diseases encountered today of unknown aetiology may be an outcome such practices. On the other hand, the processing discards of animals like goat, fish and chicken are left as such to fester in open due lack of awareness among the masses regarding its long-term implications on the environment. These festering discards if not consumed by the scavenging animals such as dogs or vultures, act as treasure of nutrients for microbes such as fungi, bacteria and viruses leading to different ailments of broadly unknown aetiology.
Nanoscience and Technology has emerged not only as an upcoming field on the spectrum of modern science and technology, rather holds many prodigal promises towards solution of many environmental problems. Along with this, it also ensures development of product from such wastes to mitigate problems being posed to our environment. Earlier, the synthesis of a variety of nanoparticles taking use of dead decaying lower animal bodies (like cockroaches, flies, mosquitoes and ants), processing wastes of higher animals such as fishes and goat had been reported by the authors’ group [1-6]. With an aim to emphasize and consolidate the versatility of nanoscience and technology, in continuation to our earlier efforts with functional pharmaceuticals [7,8], we have exemplified here the potential use of an expired pharmaceutical (Norfloxacin) and very commonly sacrificed higher animal, chicken(Gallus gallus domesticus) processing waste (Chicken gut/intestine).Along with this, further it also ensures development of product from such wastes in order to mitigate problems being posed to the environment. In the present effort, we have tried to employ the wasted pharmaceuticals and higher animal processing wastes to synthesize widely applicable nanoparticles of silver (Ag) and zinc oxide (ZnO) using simple and totally green bionanotechnology protocol which could be taken in to use for different purposes especially for environmental clean-up and/or protection.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation of broth from expired drug (Norflox-TZ)
sections.text: Four-month expired Norflox-TZ (500 mg) tablets were dissolved slowly in 100 mL sterile distilled water and was added 5 mL N/20 HCl to ensure a better degree of dissolution through gentle heating over a steam bath of up to 40°C until a light yellow colour appeared in the conical flask. Then, 25 mL of this source broth was diluted 4 times by the addition of distilled water. This source solution (pH=3) was used to synthesize different nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of culture medium from chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) processing waste
sections.text: A known quantity (200 g) chicken processing discard (principally gut) was procured from the local market. It was washed thoroughly thrice by deionized water just to discard dust or other undesired materials like blood stains along with metallic contamination, if any. The discards were immediately ground with 50% ethanol and heated gently until the colour of the mixture changes from near transparent to dark honey indicating dissolution of potentially significant metabolites. This extract was filtered cautiously after gentle toiling of the animal tissue, which was then pooled and cooled for 20 minutes at laboratory ambiance. Toiled animal tissue mass was further boiled for a defined time (10 minutes) to secure candidate metabolites. Both biosynthetic mixtures (broth) are blended together to be used for preparing nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 2.3. Biosynthesis of Silver nanoparticles (Ag NPs)
sections.text:
The diluted broths of expired Norflox-TZ as well as chicken processing discard were inoculated separately with 20 mL of 0.25(M) AgNO3 solution and warmed on the steam baths for 5 min until the colour of solutions change to deep reddish-brown and were allowed to cool and incubate in the laboratory ambience. The deposition gets distinctly visible in the both the flasks within 5 min (approx.) which were left for another 5 h and subsequently filtered separately.
A.K. Jha and K. Prasad / Materials Today: Proceedings 18 (2019) 1465–1471 1467

sections.heading: 2.4. Biosynthesis of ZnO nanoparticles (ZnO NPs)
sections.text: Analytical reagent grade zinc chloride (ZnCl2) was taken into use for preparing a solution of 0.25(M) strength at room temperature in sterile distilled water. 20 ml of solution was added to each of the diluted expired Norflox-TZ and chicken processing discard broths (without shifting the pH beyond 6), they were heated until appearance of starch like haziness in both the solutions, and white deposition at the bottom of both the flasks were noted. This was perceived as initiation of transformation. The value of pH was maintained at six because a lower value delays the procedure of oxide synthesis and a higher value leads to metallization. Both the flasks were allowed to incubate in the laboratory ambience for another four hours until duck white fluffy mass settles down leaving clear transparent supernatant at the top. They were also filtered for further studies.

sections.heading: 2.5. Characterization
sections.text: The formation of metal (Ag) and oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles were ascertained by X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique using an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, D8-Advance) with CuK radiation  = 1.5406Å over a wide range of Bragg angles (2) between 20 to 80. Transmission electron micrographs of Ag NPs and ZnO NPs were obtained using Bruker transmission electron microscope. The specimens were suspended in distilled water, dispersed ultrasonically to separate individual particles, and two drops of the suspension deposited onto holeycarbon coated copper grids.

sections.heading: 3. Results
sections.text:
Figures 1a and 1b show the TEM micrographs of the Ag NPs and ZnO NPs being formed, respectively using expired Norflox-TZ and chicken processing discard broths. All the micrographs clearly illustrate individual nanoparticles as well as a very few aggregates. The Ag NPs are found to be almost spherical in shape with particle sizes ranging between 5 to 21 nm while ZnO NPs are found to have plate like structure, which are of 8 to 40 nm in size. The difference in size may possibly be due to the fact that the nanoparticles are being formed at different times.
With the aims to ascertain, the crystal structures of Ag NPs and ZnO NPs XRD studies were carried out. Figures 2a and 2b show the XRD patterns obtained for Ag NPs and ZnO NPs synthesized, respectively using expired Norflox-TZ and chicken processing discard. The respective XRDs clearly indicate the formation of crystalline silver as well as zinc oxide nanoparticles. A number of Bragg reflections of different lattice planes of face-centered cubic (fcc) silver and hexagonal zinc oxide were indexed using a software POWD. The unit cell parameters as estimated have been depicted in Table 1. This result is in consistent with the literature earlier reports (ICDD #: 044387 and 086254). In addition, the broadening of XRD peaks is primarily due to the formation of small sized particles. The apparent particle sizes (L) for all the prepared nanoparticles were estimated by analyzing the X-ray diffraction peak broadening, using Williamson and Hall approach and are listed in Table 1. It is found that the apparent particle sizes estimated using Williamson and Hall approach to be in good agreement with the sizes estimated by TEM analysis.
1468 A.K. Jha and K. Prasad / Materials Today: Proceedings 18 (2019) 1465–1471
Hence, the present biosynthetic methods capable of synthesizing both metallic as well as oxide nanoparticles utilizing the waste materials like expired Norflox-TZ or chicken processing discard, which may be considered as a step in controlling environmental pollution to some extent.

sections.heading: 4. Discussions
sections.text:
Animal kingdom is often exposed to the metallic stress/assault through different sources in nature. However, in little amount metals help in different physiological/metabolic drives but a higher dose often causes stress in the system. Chicken like other animals have blood as carrier where metals usually are attached to proteins. Many heavy metals are used as a trace elements and feed additives in poultry feed. These metals are common in our environment some of these (iron, copper, manganese, zinc, etc.) are essential for good health, however; other (Arsenic, mercury, lead, cadmium, etc.) are poisonous and deleterious for health [9]. Arsenic is most important and usually found in the environment in organic and inorganic forms with different bioavailability. Exposing bacteria to arsenic in feed can inadvertently cause an increase in antibiotic resistance. Infectious disease concerns are heightened by the fact that poultry producers routinely use feed additives that include both antibiotics and arsenic components. Vitamin C partially ameliorated the toxic effects of arsenic in broiler birds [10]. Similarly, Lead, Mercury, Cadmium etc. could also have annihilating effect on chicken. Earlier, it was observed that the activities of erythrocyte superoxide dismutase (SOD) and catalase (CAT) increased during sub-acute cadmium toxicity. The level of blood glutathione (GSH) was significantly decreased in cadmium exposed birds [11]. A recent exhaustive study suggests the role of Ascorbic Acid (Vitamin C) as an anti-stress among poultries [12] and it may be due to their role in Glutathione metabolism.
A.K. Jha and K. Prasad / Materials Today: Proceedings 18 (2019) 1465–1471 1469
As such, when metal comes in contact with any organ of the animal body through the blood stream, it tends to get chelated and deposited and the degree of deposition may vary from one organ to another and this may be broadly dependent upon the animal cohort under consideration [13]. However, among chicken it may be deposited in liver, kidney or intestine. Animal kingdom is bestowed with naturally occurring stress buster cum chelator known as metallothionein. Genes responsible for metallothionein are triggered under heavy metal assault by specific transcription factor like MTF-1, which attaches to a short DNA sequence known as metal response elements (MREs) [14]. At the genomic level, a homolog to the mammalian MTF-1, the expression of MTs is regulated transcriptionally by metal responsive transcription factor 1 (MTF-1). MTF-1 binds to the short DNA motifs termed metal-response elements (MREs), upon metal assault, in the MT promoter, which are significant and capable of mediating the transcriptional rejoinder to heavy metals [15,16]. Finally, the cessation of cells tends to liberate the potential metabolites that help in nanomaterial fabrication depending upon the modulation of pivotal parameters. The schematics for the biosynthesis of Ag NPs and ZnO NPs using chicken processing discard are illustrated in Figure 3.
It is by dint of its organization/structure, a molecule acts as a potential pharmaceutical. Chemical structure further adds to its redox agility. Chemically, norfloxacin is 1-ethyl-6-fluoro- 1,4-dihydro-4-oxo-7-(1-piperazinyl)-3-
1470 A.K. Jha and K. Prasad / Materials Today: Proceedings 18 (2019) 1465–1471
quinoline carboxylic acid. It differs from other quinolones by having a fluorine atom at the 6 position and a piperazine moiety at the 7 position. Recent infrared spectroscopic study involving free norfloxacin exhibits very strong bands at 1729 and 1619 cm-1 which are assigned to the stretching vibration of the carboxylic ν(COOH) and the pyridone stretch ν(C=O) [17,18]. These bands disappear in the complexes that simply imply the involvement of the carboxylic group and the carbonyl oxygen atom in the interaction with metal ions. The carboxylato group can act as unidentate, bidentate or as bridging ligand, and the frequency separation [Dν=νas(COO−)-νs(COO−)] between the asymmetric and symmetric stretching of this group can be made to distinguish between these binding states [19]. Further, in a molecule of Norfloxacin, the Ketonic group present in the quinolone nucleus and the additional fluorine atom in the molecule are clear indications of its redox agility. Production of a zweitter-ion makes the milieu quite amenable for a desired nanomaterial synthesis subject to the variation of the pH value. The probable bio-synthetic mechanism is detailed in Figure 4.
Whether an expired pharmaceutical or an animal tissues; either they are made up of a single chemical or a conglomerate of different chemicals liberated in to the reaction vessel under influence of heat. Moreover, the adherence of bio-ligands and metal ions quite often result in to enrapturing co-ordination complexes. As a matter of fact, metal ions act as Lewis acid-capable of accepting lone pairs donated by the biological ligands themselves acting as Lewis base. This is well illustrated in the case of metallothionein where 30–35% of its amino acid cysteine carries soft SH-groups. The biological function of metallothioneins is to preserve the cells from toxic heavy metal assaults. Secondly, due to the favourable chelate effect, the metal chelate complexes are quite stable, because there is always a favourable entropic factor accompanying the release of non-chelating ligands. Identically, the pKa values of coordinate ligands and tuning of redox potentials also play significant role. Finally, different biopolymers affect the thermodynamic stoutness of a metal center, since it can control, through its three-dimensional structure such as stereochemistry, available ligands for coordination, local hydrophilicity and or hydrophobicity, steric blockage of coordination sites and hydrogen bonding formation. This enrapturing thermodynamic interaction and/or interdependence keeps molecules agile and ensures the formation of nanomaterials are dependent upon the modulation of experimental cues [20]. Conclusively, it may be said that if have a look with a perspective of Nanoscience and Technology - nothing is waste in nature and everything can be recycled back in the form of pollution mitigation products.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In summary, Ag and ZnO NPs have successfully been prepared using both expired Norflox-TZ as well as chicken processing discard (principally intestine). Therefore, present biosynthetic methods are capable of producing metal as well as oxide nanoparticles, which might have resulted, respectively due to the activity of metallothioneine and the formation of zweitter-ion, indicating thereby that animals’ discard and/or expired medicines too can negotiate nanotransformations. Furthermore, present work might be a step towards utilizing expired medicines and/or animal discard in synthesizing a variety of nanomaterials and consequently addressing environmental issues.

author: J.A. Asturias
N. Gómez-Bayón
M.C. Arilla
A. Martínez
R. Palacios
F. Sánchez-Gascón

This effort may help in controlling the environmental pollution and subsequently the different diseases. A simple environment friendly protocol, employing the broths of chicken processing discard (principally intestine) and expired Norflox-TZ yielded Ag as well as ZnO nanoparticles. X-ray and transmission electron microscopy analyses are performed to ascertain the formation of Ag and ZnO nanoparticles. Possible involved mechanisms for the biosynthesis of Ag and ZnO nanoparticles using chicken processing discard and expired Norflox-TZ have also been discussed. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd.
